section_1_key_concepts.overview: Forces cause objects to move, change speed, or change shape. This topic covers vectors, Newton's Laws, and motion graphs.

key_terms.definition: The single force that has the same effect as all forces acting on an object
Constant max speed reached when forces are balanced

learning_objectives: Distinguish between scalar and vector quantities
Apply Newton's Three Laws of Motion

section_2_detailed_explanations.heading: Scalars vs Vectors
section_2_detailed_explanations.content: Scalars have size only (Speed, Distance, Mass, Energy, Time). Vectors have size AND direction (Velocity, Displacement, Weight, Force, Acceleration). We represent vectors with arrows.
key_points: Speed is scalar, Velocity is vector
Mass is scalar, Weight is vector

section_2_detailed_explanations.heading: Newton's Laws
section_2_detailed_explanations.content: 1) If resultant force is zero, object remains stationary or moves at constant velocity. 2) F = ma (Force = mass × acceleration). 3) Every action has an equal and opposite reaction.

section_3_worked_examples.question: A car of mass 1000kg accelerates at 2m/s². Calculate the resultant force.

foundation.question: Is velocity a scalar or a vector?

higher.question: Explain terminal velocity of a skydiver (6 marks)
higher.correct_answer: Weight acts down; Air resistance acts up. Initially Weight > Air resistance -> accelerates. As speed increases, air resistance increases. Eventually Air resistance = Weight. Resultant force = 0. Constant speed reached.
higher.explanation: Steps: Acceleration -> Resistance Increases -> Forces Balance -> Constant Speed

common_mistakes: Thinking constant speed means 'force is constant' (Force is ZERO)
mark_scheme_notes: Show substitution into formula for method marks
